Australia: Sydney and Melbourne linked by electric telegraph.
New South Wales men achieved the right to vote.
Bangladesh: East India Company is dissolved and the British Raj begins.
Burundi: The area was visited by British explorer John Hanning Speke, who became the first European to do so.
China: The Qing dynasty signed the Treaty of Aigun, ceding to Russia the land north of the Amur River.

Second Opium War: The Qing dynasty signed the Treaty of Tientsin, under which foreigners were granted greater freedom of movement within China and France and the United Kingdom were promised war reparations.
Battle of Sanhe: A Taiping army encircled and destroyed a much smaller Qing force in Anhui.
Colombia: Mariano Ospina Rodríguez is president of the Granadine Confederation
Haiti: Forces led by Fabre Geffrard defeat Emperor Faustin's Imperial Army
Italy: Napoleon III and Cavour meet secretly in France, in Plombières-les-Bains, where they make the Plombières Agreement. They decide that Cavour will provoke rebellion in Austrian territories in Northern Italy so as to tempt Austria into making a military decision.
Japan: Anglo-Japanese Treaty of Amity and Commerce and other Ansei Treaties were signed, resulting in Ansei Purge.
Nepal: Jang Bahadur receives title of Rana
Russia: The Treaty of Aigun was signed, pushing the Russo-Chinese border east to the Amur river; Tariff Act reduces import tax.
Rwanda: The area is visited by British explorer John Hanning Speke, the first European to do so.
Singapore: Singapore is placed under the hierarchy of the Government of India, remaining as part of the Straits Settlements.
Commercial Square is renamed Raffles Place.
Tanzania: Burton and Speke reach Lake Tanganyika, the first known Europeans to do so.
USA: The first transatlantic cable is laid.
The United States becomes a party to the Treaty of Tientsin.
